title: How to Make a Yarn Pompom

steps.title: Cut a 12-inch (30.48-centimeter) piece of yarn, and set it aside.
steps.content: Cut a 12-inch (30.48-centimeter) piece of yarn, and set it aside. [2] X Research source You will be using this piece of yarn to tie your pompom together. Your fingers will be literally tied up, so it will be easier to do this part first.

steps.title: Drape your yarn around your fingers.
steps.content: Drape your yarn around your fingers. Take the rest of your yarn, and place it horizontally across your fingers. If you want a standard sized pompom, drape it across your forefinger and middle finger. If you'd like a bigger pompom, extend the yarn over your ring finger too. [3] X Expert Source Nicole Bolin Crafts & DIY Specialist Expert Interview. 29 October 2020.

steps.title: Wrap the yarn around your fingers.
steps.content: Wrap the yarn around your fingers. Do not wrap the yarn too tightly, or you will risk cutting off your circulation. If your fingers start to turn blue or purple, you are wrapping too tightly. Wrapping the yarn too tightly will also make it harder to slide it off in the end. How many times you wrap the yarn around your fingers will depend on how big you want the pompom to be: [4] X Research source If you are using two fingers, wrap the yarn 100 to 125 times. If you are using three fingers, wrap the yarn 125 to 150 times. The more you wrap, the bigger and thicker your pompom is going to be. [5] X Expert Source Nicole Bolin Crafts & DIY Specialist Expert Interview. 29 October 2020.

steps.title: Carefully pull the yarn off your fingers and set it down on top of your short piece of yarn.
steps.content: Carefully pull the yarn off your fingers and set it down on top of your short piece of yarn. Hold your yarn bundle together as you pull it off so that it doesn't come apart. Make sure that you place it in the center of your short piece of yarn.

steps.title: Tie the yarn tightly around your bundle.
steps.content: Tie the yarn tightly around your bundle. Pull both ends of the yarn towards yourself, then tie them together into a tight knot over the center of your yarn bundle. This is very important. If the knot is not tight, the pompom won't hold together. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Turn the bundle over, and tie the yarn into a double knot.
steps.content: Turn the bundle over, and tie the yarn into a double knot. Bring the two yarn ends towards yourself again, and tie them into another tight knot. Tie them together once more to make a secure double knot.

steps.title: Trim off the excess yarn, then cut through the loops to either side of the bundle.
steps.content: Trim off the excess yarn, then cut through the loops to either side of the bundle. Be sure to cut through all of the loops, or your pompom won't look right in the end. [7] X Expert Source Nicole Bolin Crafts & DIY Specialist Expert Interview. 29 October 2020.

steps.title: Fluff the pompom up.
steps.content: Fluff the pompom up. You can do this with your fingers, or by gently rolling it between your palms. Don't panic if a few strands come out; this is normal.

steps.title: Shape and neaten the pompom.
steps.content: Shape and neaten the pompom. Your pompom is mostly done, but it may look a little scruffy. Neaten it up by trimming off any long bits of yarn that stick out. Do this by carefully rotating the pompom between your fingers, and cutting away any pieces of yarn that are longer than the rest. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Use a cup to trace a circle onto a piece of cardboard.
steps.content: Use a cup to trace a circle onto a piece of cardboard. This will create the base for your pompom maker. If you want a really big pompom, you can use a small bowl or even an old CD or DVD. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Trace a smaller circle inside the first one.
steps.content: Trace a smaller circle inside the first one. The circle should be ½ to 1 inch (1.27 to 2.54 centimeters) wide. The bigger your outer circle is, the bigger your inner circle should be. Avoid making the inner circle too big, however, or you'll have a hard time tying your pompom together.

steps.title: Cut the circles out using a craft blade.
steps.content: Cut the circles out using a craft blade. Cut your larger circle out first, then the smaller one. You will end up with something that looks like a doughnut. If you are a child doing this craft, ask an adult to help you with this step.

steps.title: Cut a ½-inch (1.27-centimeter) wide slit into the doughnut.
steps.content: Cut a ½-inch (1.27-centimeter) wide slit into the doughnut. The slit needs to go from the outer edge straight down to the inner edge. This will make wrapping the yarn around your doughnut easier. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Use your doughnut to trace and cut a second one just like it.
steps.content: Use your doughnut to trace and cut a second one just like it. Stack the doughnuts one on top of the other, and make sure that the slits are aligned. You will be treating these as one doughnut until the very end. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Start wrapping the yarn around your doughnut.
steps.content: Start wrapping the yarn around your doughnut. The easiest way to do this would be to start at one edge of the slit, going all the way around your doughnut, and finishing at the other edge of the slit.

steps.title: Keep wrapping the yarn, back and forth, across your doughnut until the center hole is full.
steps.content: Keep wrapping the yarn, back and forth, across your doughnut until the center hole is full. Try to wrap as evenly as you can, and not so tightly that the cardboard starts to twist and warp. [12] X Research source If you'd like, you can switch yarn colors to create a more interesting-looking pompom. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Cut the yarn.
steps.content: Cut the yarn. Snip off the excess yarn first, then slid your scissors between the yarn and the cardboard. Pull your scissors towards the edge of your doughnut, and start cutting through the yarn. Hold your yarn together, and don't let it come apart.

steps.title: Cut a long piece of yarn, and tie it around the middle of your yarn bundle.
steps.content: Cut a long piece of yarn, and tie it around the middle of your yarn bundle. Separate your two cardboard doughnuts enough so that you can slide your yarn in between them. Tie the ends of your yarn into a tight knot. Wrap them back in the opposite direction, then tie them into a tight, double knot. [14] X Research source You can choose to snip off the excess pieces of yarn, or you can tie the ends into a loop so that you can hang it.

steps.title: Carefully pull the cardboard doughnuts off of your pompom.
steps.content: Carefully pull the cardboard doughnuts off of your pompom. If you need to, you can tear them to make things easier, but keep in mind that if you do that, you won't be able to reuse them.

steps.title: Fluff up the pompom.
steps.content: Fluff up the pompom. You can do this by gently going through it with your fingers. You can also roll it between your palms instead. Don't worry if a few pieces of yarn come out.

steps.title: Neaten and even your pompom out.
steps.content: Neaten and even your pompom out. Your pompom might still have some scraggly bits coming off of it, especially after all that fluffing. Rotate the pompom between your fingers, and snip off any long pieces of yarn that stick out.

steps.title: Place the end of your yarn horizontally across the prongs of a fork.
steps.content: Place the end of your yarn horizontally across the prongs of a fork. You can use a plastic fork, but a metal fork will be less likely to bend or snap. Because you are working with such a small tool, consider working with a thinner type of yarn, rather than a bulky type.

steps.title: Wrap the yarn around 90 times, then trim the rest off.
steps.content: Wrap the yarn around 90 times, then trim the rest off. Do not wrap the yarn too tightly, or you will bend the fork. Not only will you ruin the fork, but the pompom may not come out even. It will also make the pompom more difficult to tie at the end.

steps.title: Cut a 12-inch (30.48-centimeter) piece of yarn.
steps.content: Cut a 12-inch (30.48-centimeter) piece of yarn. You will be using this to tie your pompom together. If you want, you can thread this through a yarn needle. This will make tying your pompom together easier.

steps.title: Wrap the short piece of yarn tightly around the wrapped yarn on your fork.
steps.content: Wrap the short piece of yarn tightly around the wrapped yarn on your fork. Thread the yarn through the middle of the fork, right under the wrapped yarn first. Next, wrap it over the top of the wrapped yarn, and back under it, as tightly as you can.

steps.title: Tie the short piece of yarn into a tight, double knot.
steps.content: Tie the short piece of yarn into a tight, double knot. Snip off any excess yarn, or tie it into a loop if you'd like to hang your pompom.

steps.title: Slide the wrapped yarn off of the fork, then snip through the loops on either side.
steps.content: Slide the wrapped yarn off of the fork, then snip through the loops on either side. Gently fluffy the pompom out. You can do this with your fingers, or by rolling it between our palms. Don't worry if you lose a few threads.

steps.title: Even out the pompom.
steps.content: Even out the pompom. At this point, you are done. Your pompom may look a little bit scraggly, however. If this bothers you, use a pair of scissors to trim off any uneven bits of yarn so that you get a ball-shape. This will also help make your pompom look more dense.
